author: By Juliet Macur
title: Gymnastics Learns a New Trick: Athletes Talk and Coaches Listen
description: Changes in the sport, which is still struggling to recover from a sexual abuse scandal, were evident at a championship event in Texas.
content: FORT WORTH — Sarah Jantzi, an elite gymnastics coach and the whistle-blower in the biggest sexual abuse scandal in sports history, trains her athletes using an approach that for years some fellow coaches considered unconventional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kovie Biakolo
title: ‘Run the World’ Is an Ode to ‘Enviable Friendships’ and Black Harlem
description: This Starz series about four women “walking into real adulthood,” as the creator described it, is broadly appealing but unmistakably based in Black women’s perspectives.
content: For nearly three decades, Yvette Lee Bowser has created, produced and written for television shows that portray women who have what she calls “enviable female friendships.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: U.S. Women’s Open: Yuka Saso Wins, Extending a Majors Drought by Americans
description: Yuka Saso of the Philippines won her first major, beating Nasa Hataoka of Japan in the first sudden-death playoff hole after they remained tied after two-hole aggregate playoff.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Yuka Saso of the Philippines bent her leg like a flamingo, using her body language to will in the birdie putt. It was the first playoff hole after Saso and Nasa Hataoka of Japan finished 72 holes of the 76th United States Women’s Open on Sunday tied at four-under 280, one stroke better than the third-round leader, the American Lexi Thompson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Luis Arias won a split decision in an exciting bout.
description: Before the eighth round of Luis Arias’s middleweight bout against Jarrett Hurd, trainer Ismael Salas told his fighter the key to sealing a victory against a bigger, stronger opponent.
content: Before the eighth round of Luis Arias’s middleweight bout against Jarrett Hurd, trainer Ismael Salas told his fighter the key to sealing a victory against a bigger, stronger opponent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Vincent Tullo
title: Look Inside Philip Roth’s Personal Library
description: The author of “Goodbye, Columbus” and “The Human Stain” left several thousand books, many of them with notes or letters, to the Newark Public Library. The collection will soon open to the public.
content: NEWARK — Philip Roth was not precious about the books in his personal library.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: U.S. 3, Mexico 2: All the Plot Twists
description: Sunday’s Concacaf Nations League final was a roller-coaster of emotion, a game of goals and fights, flying projectiles and video reviews. It ended with the United States lifting the trophy.
content: You will not find the word Concacaffy in any dictionary, but any soccer fan in North America knows what it means and how to use it in a sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Falling in Love With Weehawken
description: The New Jersey town felt like home right away, and the pandemic made it even more so.
content: An inexpensive apartment brought Frank Gargiulo to Weehawken, N.J., seven years ago. But it’s a different apartment — a beautiful, sunny 1,300-square-foot space with a sunroom, a terrace and Victorian details like bay windows and pocket doors — that has kept him there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Tran
title: Akwaeke Emezi: ‘Imagine Being Ogbanje, Like Me’
description: “Dear Senthuran” is an epistolary memoir of gender identity, diaspora and the solitude of success.
content: DEAR SENTHURAN A Black Spirit Memoir By Akwaeke Emezi
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Streaming problems? You’re not alone.
description: It is a big pay-per-view event, which means people are complaining that their stream is going down.
content: It is a big pay-per-view event, which means people are complaining that their stream is going down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marion Renault
title: This Tiny Creature Survived 24,000 Years Frozen in Siberian Permafrost
description: The microscopic animals were frozen when woolly mammoths still roamed the planet, but were restored as though no time had passed.
content: Bdelloid rotifers may be the toughest, tiniest animal you’ve never heard of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Jett
title: New Dinosaur Species Is Australia’s Largest, Researchers Say
description: Australotitan cooperensis, a long-necked herbivore from the Cretaceous period, is estimated to have weighed 70 tons, measured two stories tall and extended the length of a basketball court.
content: Robyn and Stuart Mackenzie, riding motorbikes one day in 2006 on their vast sheep and cattle farm in the Australian outback, spotted a pile of what looked like large black rocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall and Stephanie Saul
title: Gripped by ‘Dinner Party-gate,’ Yale Law Confronts a Venomous Divide
description: A dispute centering on the celebrity professor Amy Chua exposes a culture pitting student against student, professor against professor.
content: NEW HAVEN, Conn. — On March 26, a group of students at Yale Law School approached the dean’s office with an unusual accusation: Amy Chua, one of the school’s most popular but polarizing professors, had been hosting drunken dinner parties with students, and possibly federal judges, during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In Her New Memoir, Ursula M. Burns Recounts Blazing a Trail to the Top of Xerox
description: Burns, the first Black female C.E.O. of a Fortune 500 company, tells her story in “Where You Are Is Not Who You Are.”
content: There’s a thriving trade in what are sometimes called “executive book summaries.” These are CliffsNotes for the harried managerial class. New business books are crunched down to a few pages of bullet points, so supervisors can consume them on the run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Oscar Lopez
title: Mexico President’s Grip on Congress Slips, Showing Limits of His Mandate
description: Early results of midterm elections suggested that Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s coalition would not obtain the supermajority needed to push through his ambitious agenda.
content: MEXICO CITY — Voters in Mexico tapped the brakes on President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s ambitious plans to overhaul the country’s economy and society by narrowing his leftist coalition’s majority in Congress in midterm elections on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: How Thousands of Indigenous Children Vanished in Canada
description: The discovery of the remains of 215 children at the site of a defunct boarding school in British Columbia has rekindled discussion of a sinister time in Canada’s history.
content: OTTAWA — The announcement last month that the remains of 215 Indigenous children had been found on the grounds of the Kamloops Indian Residential School left the nation reeling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sonali Deraniyagala
title: The Year We Battled Covid, Revisited
description: In “The Plague Year,” Lawrence Wright tells the story of the pandemic that upended all of our lives — both the failures to combat it, and the science that saved us.
content: THE PLAGUE YEARAmerica in the Time of CovidBy Lawrence Wright
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Dangerous Delta Variant
description: Covid cases are rising in Britain — and U.S. trends may soon follow.
content: Britain has had one of the world’s most successful Covid-19 responses in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Catie Edmondson, David McCabe and Thomas Kaplan
title: Senate Poised to Pass Huge Industrial Policy Bill to Counter China
description: The broad support for the bill highlights how competition with Beijing is one of the few issues that can still unite both political parties.
content: WASHINGTON — Faced with an urgent competitive threat from China, the Senate is poised to pass the most expansive industrial policy legislation in U.S. history, blowing past partisan divisions over government support for private industry to embrace a nearly quarter-trillion-dollar investment in building up America’s manufacturing and technological edge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Start Your Morning With Ai Weiwei
description: The artist is the latest to collaborate with Illy on espresso and cappuccino cups.
content: Since 1992, the Italian coffee company Illy has commissioned artists to decorate special editions of their espresso and cappuccino cups. More than 100 painters, sculptors and even filmmakers have participated. The latest is the Chinese artist and activist Ai Weiwei, who has splashed the ceramic cups and saucers with color and gilding. The designs were inspired by the “Colored Vases” project he began in 2006.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Industrial Policy, Alzheimer’s, Pizza: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Why All the Fury at Apple?
description: Some developers are sick of Apple being a dictator. Apple says it’s protecting us. Let’s dissect this.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan and Kevin Armstrong
title: High School Student Fatally Shot Near Soccer Field Where He Excelled
description: Moussa Fofana, 18, a junior at Columbia High School in Maplewood, N.J., and another student were hit by gunfire on Sunday night.
content: Moussa Fofana became fixated on soccer in middle school, honing his skills at all hours, his mother said. The pandemic may have upended his life in other ways over the past academic year, his third in high school, but it could not dim his passion for the game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Blindspotting’ and ‘Betty’
description: A TV adaptation of Daveed Diggs and Rafael Casal’s “Blindspotting” debuts on Starz. And Crystal Moselle’s “Betty” returns for a second season on HBO.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 7-June 13. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aman Sethi
title: Why Amazon Is Confronting the Richest Man in India
description: The American company sees big potential in the country’s nascent e-commerce market. Both sides view a troubled grocery store chain as the key to success.
content: NEW DELHI — Amazon and one of the world’s richest men are engaged in a multibillion-dollar, politically fraught clash over Rani Pillai’s favorite place to buy groceries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Wedding Bells for Two 95 Year Olds
description: Joy Morrow-Nulton and John Shults Jr., both widowed twice after 60-plus years of marriage, celebrated their 95th birthdays and wedding.
content: Joy Morrow-Nulton keeps a diary, but she doesn’t need it to remember the date of her first lunch with John Shults Jr. in upstate New York. “It was May 14, 2019, and the restaurant was A Slice of Italy,” Ms. Morrow-Nulton, 95, said. The specifics of their conversation mostly escape her because she was bored. But two years later, she is pleased she pretended otherwise and stuck it out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Katie Rogers
title: Dreams of Ending the Filibuster Dashed, Democrats Rethink Strategy
description: President Biden and his party searched for a way forward on their ambitious agenda after one of their own, Joe Manchin III, closed the door on ending the filibuster.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden and Senate Democrats confronted a narrowing set of options on Monday for moving ahead with their ambitious agenda, as the reality set in that they would not be able to maneuver past rules that empower Republicans to block most of their legislative proposals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Women’s Prison Plagued by Sexual Violence Will Close, Governor Says
description: Gov. Philip D. Murphy said that he would shut down Edna Mahan, New Jersey’s only women’s prison, because of a “long history of abusive incidents.”
content: Just over a year ago, the Justice Department offered a scathing indictment of New Jersey’s only prison for women, describing a culture of sexual violence by guards so entrenched that it violated prisoners’ constitutional protections from cruel and unusual punishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Journalists at The Atlantic unionize, the latest in a wave of media organizing.
description: Jeffrey Goldberg, The Atlantic’s editor in chief, said the company would voluntarily recognize the new union.
content: The Atlantic intends to voluntarily recognize a newly formed union of editorial workers, the magazine’s editor in chief, Jeffrey Goldberg, said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Lalena Fisher
title: Surprise: Women and Minorities Are Still Underrepresented in Corporate Boardrooms
description: The latest version of a multiyear analysis of Fortune 100 and 500 companies found that white women made some gains but that true representation is decades away.
content: — Linda Akutagawa, chair for the Alliance for Board Diversity and chief executive of Leadership Education for Asian Pacifics
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Taylor
title: Summer’s Greatest Prize: Watermelons, With Seeds, Please
description: For many Americans, juicy, scarlet watermelon is a must for Juneteenth. The heirloom varieties are a sacred summer fruit.
content: In the fervor of June, heirloom watermelon varieties flourish in backyard gardens and family-run microfarms throughout the American South. Their scarlet-colored flesh, stippled with black seeds, is a striking relic of summers past in comparison to the seedless supermarket varieties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Gallery Weekend Brings London’s Art Scene Back to Life
description: The event, spread out through the city’s dealerships, brought a model tried elsewhere to one of the sector’s major capitals.
content: LONDON — “I met her on a dating app … I met her in a pub,” said Ellie Pennick, 24, director and founder of Guts Gallery, recalling on Friday how she had discovered some of the young artists whose work she was selling from a pop-up space near Carnaby Street during the debut edition of London Gallery Weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hanc
title: For Small Gyms, Handling the Pandemic Meant Expanding
description: From on-demand video libraries to rooftop classes, boutique workout spots broadened beyond their tight spaces.
content: This article is part of Owning the Future, a series on how small businesses across the country have been affected by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Kreda
title: Mathew Barzal Finds Scoring Touch for Islanders
description: Barzal, the team’s points leader for four straight seasons, broke a goal-less postseason last week and had the game-winner to tie the series with Boston ahead of Game 5.
content: Islanders fans had become used to seeing Mathew Barzal score. But through the first eight playoff games this spring, Barzal, the team’s points leader for each of the past four seasons, did not have a goal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Exiting Pac-12 Chief Urges a Bigger Playoff and a More Responsive N.C.A.A.
description: Larry Scott, the commissioner of the westernmost Power 5 conference since 2009, will leave at the end of June with a decidedly mixed record.
content: Larry Scott, the Pac-12 commissioner since 2009, is preparing to step away under pressure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: At Sona, a Feast From All Around India
description: At a new restaurant in Manhattan, the chef Hari Nayak presents specialties from many regions.
content: One way you know New York City isn’t “dead forever,” among other fatuous prophecies of doom that wafted about in the depths of the lockdown, is that people who want to advertise themselves and their ideas are still using the city as a billboard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: New Musical About 19th-Century New York Plans Broadway Run
description: “Paradise Square,” a comeback bid by a scandal-scarred producer, is the first previously unscheduled musical to announce its Broadway opening since the pandemic began.
content: “Paradise Square,” a new musical that explores race relations in 19th-century New York, plans to open on Broadway next winter, making it the first previously unscheduled musical to step forward since the pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: A New Contemporary Art Museum Aims to Heal a City’s Wounds
description: Twelve years after a powerful earthquake devastated L’Aquila, in central Italy, the building’s inauguration is a sign of recovery. But there is still work to do.
content: L’AQUILA, Italy — On a recent sunny morning, things were kicking into high gear in the Piazza Santa Maria Paganica, a square in the central Italian city of L’Aquila. Assorted officials, their entourages, journalists, passers-by and museum staff mingled excitedly in front of a Baroque palazzo, which was about to be opened as Italy’s newest bastion of contemporary art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: For an Extra Special Celebration
description: Louis Roederer has released its top-tier Champagne, the 2013 Cristal vintage.
content: Graduation, Father’s Day, a wedding, all occasions that warrant raising a glass of bubbly. This year perhaps a splurge is in order. Champagne Louis Roederer recently released the 2013 Cristal, the company’s tête de cuvée first created in 1876 for Czar Alexander II and not made annually. Using biodynamic grapes from old vines in a 60 percent pinot noir, 40 percent chardonnay blend, the golden bubbly aged for seven years has a lightly toasted, savory aroma, hints of tart plums, mouth-filling complexity and finesse for what is truly a special occasion quaff. The bottle itself has some uncommon features that were required by the czar: There’s no punt (indentation) in the bottom to prevent anarchists from hiding explosives there, and the bottle is clear, not green, so it’s easy to tell that nothing nasty has been added to the liquid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Google to Pay $270 Million to Settle Antitrust Charges in France
description: The tech giant, which is facing similar scrutiny in the U.S., also said it would make changes to increase transparency of its online ad systems.
content: LONDON — Google agreed to pay roughly $270 million in fines and change some of its business practices as part of a settlement announced on Monday with French antitrust regulators who had accused the company of abusing its dominance of the online advertising market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein, Jeffery C. Mays, Jazmine Hughes, Anne Barnard, Michael Gold and Mihir Zaveri
title: Wiley Wins the Progressives: 5 Takeaways From the N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race
description: With just two weeks to go before the primary, Maya Wiley is consolidating support from the left wing of the Democratic Party.
content: With two weeks to go before the Democratic primary, the progressive left has seemed to have coalesced around a single candidate, relying on a time-honored technique: self-elimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi, Matt Furber and Coral Davenport
title: Police Make Mass Arrests at Protest Against Oil Pipeline
description: Late Monday, police arrested activists and appeared to use a crowd-dispelling sonic device at the Line 3 pipeline in Minnesota, which would carry oil across sensitive waterways and tribal lands.
content: PARK RAPIDS, MINN. — The protesters who gathered in the boreal forests of Northern Minnesota came from across the country — Native American tribes and their supporters, environmentalists and religious leaders — all to fight an expansion of Line 3, a $9 billion pipeline operated by the Canadian company, Enbridge, that would carry hundreds of thousands of barrels of oil through Minnesota’s delicate watersheds and tribal lands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Republicans win two Texas mayoral races, including one in McAllen, which is 85 percent Hispanic.
description: Texas Republicans, who performed well with Hispanic voters in the 2020 election, showed further strength by winning the races in Democratic counties.
content: Republicans in Texas celebrated on Monday after winning two closely watched mayoral elections in the state on Saturday, taking control of cities in Democratic counties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: 2 Trains Collide in Pakistan, Killing at Least 35
description: Most of the passengers on an express train were asleep when it derailed and its cars fell across the track into the path of another.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Two express trains collided in southern Pakistan on Monday, killing at least 35 passengers and injuring 115 others, officials said, the latest in a series of accidents that have raised serious questions about the safety of rail travel in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: In Australia, a Peek at Broadway’s Comeback
description: When The Times staged a musical number for its live event series, the performance served as a sneak preview of a theater world preparing for takeoff.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Carbon Dioxide in Atmosphere Hits Record High Despite Pandemic Dip
description: Global emissions dropped last year, but the decline wasn’t nearly enough to halt the buildup of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.
content: The amount of carbon dioxide piling up in Earth’s atmosphere set a record last month, once again reaching the highest levels in human history despite a temporary dip in the burning of fossil fuels worldwide caused by the coronavirus pandemic, scientists said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Yankees Find Life Without Left-Handed Batters Isn’t Right
description: Alex Rodriguez shredded the team’s lineup for being so one-dimensional. They’ll have to adjust to become contenders.
content: If this were 2020 — and let’s never go back there, please — the Yankees’ regular season would be over after 60 games. They would still be alive, but eagerly rooting for other teams to lose, allowing them to qualify for the eighth spot in a bloated playoff field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: How the ‘Alpha’ Coronavirus Variant Became So Powerful
description: A new study suggests how the variant first identified in Britain hides from the human immune system. Its stealth may be part of its success.
content: In December, British researchers discovered that a new variant was sweeping through their country. When it arrived in other countries, the variant, now known as Alpha, tended to become more common in its new homes as well. By April, it had become the dominant variant in the United States, and it has remained so ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: 2 Arrested in California Road-Rage Shooting That Killed a 6-Year-Old
description: Marcus Anthony Eriz , 24, and Wynne Lee , 23, are expected to be charged with murder in the May 21 killing of Aiden Leos.
content: Two people have been arrested in a road-rage shooting on a freeway in Orange County, Calif., last month in which a 6-year-old boy was killed while his mother was driving him to school, the authorities announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Lisa Lerer
title: Rejecting Biden’s Win, Rising Republicans Attack Legitimacy of Elections
description: The next generation of aspiring G.O.P. congressional leaders has aggressively pushed Donald Trump’s false fraud claims, raising the prospect that the results of elections will continue to be challenged through 2024.
content: A Republican House candidate from Wisconsin says he is appalled by the violence he witnessed at the Jan. 6 rally that turned into the siege at the Capitol. But he did not disagree with G.O.P. lawmakers’ effort to overturn the presidential election results that night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: This TikTok Star Is Turning the Tables on Microaggressions
description: Clare Brown uses the platform to share satirical videos in which white people are treated as a minority.
content: Name: Clare Brown, a.k.a @clarabellecwb
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Say It With Steelhead Trout
description: A new grilling kit from Hudson Valley Fisheries is suitable for Father’s Day.
content: Steelhead is actually a rainbow trout with wanderlust. The fish, with orange-pink flesh like salmon, goes out to sea then returns to a river to spawn. It also grows much bigger than a typical trout. Steelhead are now being raised sustainably in tanks on land in Hudson, N.Y. Though a bit more delicate than Atlantic salmon, to which it is related, it is excellent on the grill. With that in mind, Hudson Valley Fisheries has introduced a gift package serving up to six people with two pounds of fillets, two cedar planks, some seasoning rub and horseradish Dijon sauce from Talbott & Arding, also in Hudson. Think Father’s Day or a gift for a summer weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York City Is Reopening. But Some Aren’t Celebrating Yet.
description: After a year of cancellations and delays, some people are still cautious about planning large gatherings.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Looking to Tackle Prescription Overload
description: Older adults often take more medications than they need, or than is safe. Increasingly, geriatric experts and their patients are exploring the benefits of “deprescribing.”
content: The last straw, for Leslie Hawkins, was her mother’s 93rd-birthday gathering in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Coach K’s Retirement and the End of the College ‘Supercoach’
description: Mike Krzyzewski of Duke announced his retirement shortly after his Tobacco Road nemesis, Roy Williams, announced his, as the N.C.A.A prepares to grant athletes greater agency.
content: Is the supercoach soon to be extinct?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: A House Divided: A Palestinian, a Settler and the Struggle for East Jerusalem
description: Efforts to force Palestinians from Sheikh Jarrah set the stage for the recent Gaza war. A similar dynamic looms in a nearby district.
content: JERUSALEM — Few places in East Jerusalem show the struggle over the city more intimately than a four-story house on a narrow alley in the Silwan district.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Richard Robinson Dies at 84; Turned Scholastic Into an Empire
description: With help from Harry Potter, the Magic School Bus and the Baby-Sitters Club, he created the largest publisher and distributor of children’s books.
content: Richard Robinson, who took over his father’s magazine company, Scholastic, and transformed it into a behemoth in the children’s book industry with the “Harry Potter” and “Hunger Games” series and titles like “The Magic School Bus” and “Goosebumps,” died on Saturday in Chilmark, Mass., on Martha’s Vineyard. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Milk Bar Expands to Ice Cream
description: Christina Tosi has just launched a line of ice creams by the pint, inspired by flavors from her popular bakeries.
content: Nothing bears the trademark of the pastry chef Christina Tosi more than her cereal milk flavor. Often available as soft-serve at her Milk Bar confectionaries, cereal milk is now an ice cream, available by the pint. Cereal milk is not an alternate vegan ingredient made by pressing and hydrating Froot Loops or the like. It’s the milk that has soaked the cornflakes in your bowl and taken on their flavor. It’s the star in Ms. Tosi’s new line of ice creams, riddled with crunchy cornflake bits. The other flavors are birthday cake, another signature; cornflake-chocolate chip-marshmallow; and Milk Bar pie swirled with caramel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Arizona’s election review poses risks for Republicans and Democracy.
description: The Republican State Senate’s autopsy of the 2020 vote, broadly seen as a shambolic, partisan effort to nurse grievances about Donald J. Trump’s loss here in November, risks driving away some of the very people the party needs to win statewide elections in 2022.
content: The Republican State Senate’s autopsy of the 2020 vote, broadly seen as a shambolic, partisan effort to nurse grievances about Donald J. Trump’s loss here in November, risks driving away some of the very people the party needs to win statewide elections in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Boston Police Commissioner Is Fired After Domestic Violence Allegations Emerge
description: Dennis White had served for two days before he was placed on leave because of accusations from two decades ago. He has dismissed them as false and tainted by racism.
content: BOSTON — Kim Janey, Boston’s acting mayor, announced on Monday that she had terminated the city’s police commissioner, Dennis White, over allegations of domestic abuse that emerged in February, shortly after he was appointed to the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Badou Jack stopped Dervin Colina in the fourth round.
description: Dervin Colina came to fight.
content: Dervin Colina came to fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Pair of Arizona Wildfires Burns Tens of Thousands of Acres
description: No deaths or injuries have been reported in the blazes east of Phoenix, and the causes are under investigation.
content: A pair of wildfires in Arizona have burned tens of thousands of acres and forced hundreds of residents to evacuate, the latest in what experts fear will prove to be an unusually damaging and dangerous fire season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Niraj Chokshi
title: Hospital workers in Texas protest a mandatory vaccine policy.
description: Some employees at Houston Methodist object to the hospital’s requirement that staff members be vaccinated against Covid-19.
content: Dozens of staff members at a Houston-area hospital protested on Monday night against a policy that requires employees to be vaccinated against Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: ICE meant to capture drug lords. Did it snare duped older Americans instead?
description: Operation Cocoon aimed to disrupt international drug trafficking rings, but critics say it has left unwitting elderly “mules” in foreign prisons.
content: After two decades in the military, after earning two master’s degrees and navigating a successful career as a corporate coach, Victor Stemberger seemed ready for a peaceful retirement. But he had a new venture in the works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: She Was Deeply Moved by Refugees’ Stories. So She Told Them in Song.
description: “Song to a Refugee,” an inadvertent concept album from the singer and songwriter Diana Jones, strives to center the voices of migrant women.
content: Diana Jones is known as a singer-songwriter of uncommon empathy, an astute observer of the human condition whose heart goes out to those who suffer and are oppressed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alphonso David
title: Why the Latest Republican Assault on L.G.B.T.Q. Rights Is Different
description: Unprecedented legislative attacks aimed at trans people are underway. People in power need to defy these anti-L.G.B.T.Q. laws.
content: Last month, Gov. Bill Lee of Tennessee signed into law a discriminatory bill to prevent transgender people from using restrooms aligning with their gender identity at any business or place of public accommodation. A few days earlier, Governor Lee signed an anti-transgender student bathroom bill, too. These are the first bathroom bills to be enacted since North Carolina’s notorious HB2 in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: From “awful” to “good.”
content: Over the last 15 months, I’ve relied on my colleague Mitch Smith, who tracks the coronavirus for The Times, to explain the virus situation in the U.S. for this newsletter. In the past, when talking about the national outlook, he commonly used words like “terrible,” lousy” and “awful.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Mayweather and Paul go the distance, to the delight of few in attendance.
description: It didn’t end in a knockout, but the outcome was as expected. Floyd Mayweather Jr., the greatest boxer of this generation, exerted little energy in an exhibition bout against Logan Paul, a social media star with essentially no experience, earning millions of dollars in the process.
content: It didn’t end in a knockout, but the outcome was as expected. Floyd Mayweather Jr., the greatest boxer of this generation, exerted little energy in an exhibition bout against Logan Paul, a social media star with essentially no experience, earning millions of dollars in the process.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Will Netanyahu Fall?
description: How a political coalition has come to threaten the position of Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has always sold himself as a peerless defender of his country. In the minds of many Israelis, he has become a kind of indispensable leader for the nation’s future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Gonzalez and Bogaerts Power Red Sox to Sweep of Yankees
description: Boston had not had a three-game sweep in New York since 2011. Marcus Stroman led the Mets over the Padres.
content: Eager to reverse a recent trend, Marwin Gonzalez, Xander Bogaerts and the Boston Red Sox are off to a terrific start against their old rivals this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: In Arizona 2020 Election Review, Risks for Republicans, and Democracy
description: Experts call it a circus. Polls say it will hurt the G.O.P. in 2022. But Republicans are on board in Arizona and elsewhere, despite warnings of lasting damage to the political system.
content: SURPRISE, Ariz. — Rob Goins is 57, a former Marine and a lifelong Republican in a right-leaning jigsaw of golf courses, strip malls and gated retirement communities pieced together in the Arizona desert. But ask about the Republican-backed review of Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s 2020 election victory here in Maricopa County, and Mr. Goins rejects the party line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez, Lazaro Gamio and Amy Schoenfeld Walker
title: The American South could see a summer Covid surge as vaccinations lag.
description: In 15 states, including Arkansas, the Carolinas, Georgia and Louisiana, about half of adults or fewer have received a vaccine dose.
content: Experts are concerned that states across the U.S. South, where vaccination rates are lagging, could face a surge in coronavirus cases over the summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Moriyama
title: Living on the Margins, ‘Surfing’ on the Buses
description: In the Brazilian city of Olinda, a group of thrill seekers has taken up an illegal and death-defying hobby: riding on the outside of public buses.
content: “Hold on! Hold on tight!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: See You in 2022: Wary New Yorkers Are Delaying Celebrations Again
description: Many people are putting off wedding receptions, bar mitzvahs and quinceañeras, underscoring persistent fears about the virus.
content: On many weekdays this time of the year, the Aqua Azul, a 120-foot, four-level private yacht, would be wafting down the Hudson River, past the Statue of Liberty, as United Nations ambassadors marking the arrival or departure of a fellow delegate gorged on platters of spit-roast pork stuffed with dried fruit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: For Wildlife, It’s Nursery Season. Please Don’t Steal Their Babies.
description: We were a team, this baby bird and me, and if I didn’t know how foolish it would be to keep it, I totally would have kept it.
content: NASHVILLE — My whole family was in the yard on Memorial Day when my middle son noticed something small and gray balanced on the trunk of his brother’s car, which was parked just off the driveway under a large white pine. It was a baby bird — a wee baby bird, partly bald and partly fuzzy, hardly bigger than a quarter. Far too young to be out of the nest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: N.Y. businesses can choose to end most remaining limits, the governor says.
description: It would become optional for retail establishments, restaurants, offices, gyms, hair salons and other businesses to impose health precautions on their premises, though the state would abide by mask guidance from the C.D.C.
content: New York will lift most of its remaining pandemic-era restrictions on businesses and social settings once 70 percent of the state’s adults have received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Kenneth Chang
title: Jeff Bezos Will Fly Aboard Blue Origin’s First Human Trip to Space
description: Mr. Bezos and his brother, Mark, will be on board when his rocket company launches its first human spaceflight next month, shortly after he steps down as chief executive of Amazon.
content: In the battle of billionaires with rocket companies, Jeff Bezos will finally beat Elon Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Boko Haram Leader Really Did Kill Himself, Audio Message Says
description: A notorious terrorist leader in Nigeria who kidnapped schoolgirls in Chibok has blown himself up, according to a new audio recording attributed to the head of a rival extremist group.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — The head of Nigeria’s best-known terrorist group, Boko Haram, has been reported dead many times before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: India’s central government will take over vaccinations amid criticism over its handling of the outbreak.
description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi also said shots would be free for all those over 18.
content: Amid criticism of the government’s handling of one of the world’s deadliest outbreaks, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India said on Monday that the federal government would play a bigger role procuring Covid-19 vaccines on behalf of states. It’s a process that had been mired in confusion because of squabbling between the central and state governments and a lack of vaccine supply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Truck Attack That Killed a Muslim Family in Canada Was Planned
description: The police in London, Ontario, say that a 20-year-old driver planned the killings and picked the family because of its faith.
content: OTTAWA — The driver of a pickup truck in London, Ontario, who ran down five pedestrians, killing four of them, chose his victims because they were Muslim, the police said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Simone Biles Makes Another U.S. Championship Look Easy
description: Biles cruised to a record seventh U.S. title on Sunday. The team that will join her in Tokyo is starting to take shape, too.
content: The United States Gymnastics Championships concluded over the weekend, and few could have been surprised that Simone Biles dominated the competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: We Could All Use a Health Coach
description: Health coaches can give patients the tools they need to improve their own care and well-being, but they aren’t widely available.
content: Are you among the 133 million Americans suffering from one or more chronic health conditions? Conditions like diabetes, high blood pressure, heart disease, obesity, arthritis, respiratory or digestive disease, among others that can diminish the quality of your life?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Andrew Yang Is Hit With Negative Ads From Animal Rights Leaders
description: In 2013, the animal rights leaders helped undermine the mayoral campaign of Christine Quinn, boosting the chances of the eventual winner, Bill de Blasio.
content: The last time there was a crowded race for mayor of New York City, a curious issue gained unexpected prominence: Just about every major candidate promised to do away with Central Park’s horse-drawn carriages, citing concerns over the horses’ safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Start your week with a delightful potato chip omelet, or classic, comforting recipes for macaroni and potato salad.
content: Good morning. It’s funny, what professional food people get up to, cooking at home. I love the celery toasts the chef and writer Gabrielle Hamilton adds to her snack trays, and the tinned fish that leads our restaurant critic, Pete Wells, to declare himself “at least 35 percent sardine.” And I’m a big fan of the potato chip omelet (above) that the chef Ferran Adrià makes for his family, a quicker take on a Spanish tortilla that you can make with supplies picked up at the corner store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Brian X. Chen
title: Apple unveils new privacy features, digital IDs and changes to FaceTime.
description: Apple’s privacy push has put the company at odds with rivals. Despite protests from some corners of Silicon Valley, Monday’s announcements show that Apple has doubled down on privacy features.
content: Apple once again took aim at the vast digital-advertising industry on Monday and unveiled a number of changes to protect iPhones users’ privacy and strengthen its position as a gatekeeper between consumers and the rest of the digital industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wang Feng and Yong Cai
title: The Real Reason Behind China’s Three-Child Policy
description: Even when the Communist Party eases rules, it is only confirming that such rules exist — and that they are the party’s to dictate.
content: More than five years after the Chinese government abandoned its one-child policy, allowing married couples to have two children, it has now announced that they could have up to three.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rules Against Immigrants Seeking Green Cards
description: The justices said immigrants with “temporary protected status” who entered the country without authorization may not apply for lawful permanent residency.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled unanimously on Monday that immigrants allowed to stay in the United States temporarily for humanitarian reasons may not apply for green cards if they had entered the country unlawfully.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Silicon Valley’s Thin Skins and Giant Egos
description: Ellen Pao, the former C.E.O. of Reddit, talks Big Tech boys’ clubs, content moderation and workplace culture.
content: From allegations that Bill Gates had been coming on to Microsoft employees to the $22.5 million settlement of a gender discrimination suit against Pinterest, women in Silicon Valley are speaking out against what is still a male-dominated culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Anthony Weiner’s Not Coming Back. But He Has Nowhere to Go.
description: The man who was almost New York’s mayor talks about the current campaign, selling tweets and why he feels bad for the media.
content: Anthony Weiner doesn’t pay the kind of attention to New York politics that he did back when he was running for mayor, twice, before the exchange of messages with a 15-year-old that sent him to federal prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: David Dushman, Soviet Soldier Who Helped Liberate Auschwitz, Dies at 98
description: Mr. Dushman is believed to have been the last surviving liberator of the camp. He went on to become a decorated fencer.
content: BERLIN — David Dushman, who as a soldier for the Soviet Union drove his tank through the electric fence surrounding the Nazi death camp at Auschwitz on Jan. 27, 1945, and is believed to have been the last surviving liberator of the camp, died in Munich on Saturday. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: With Mayweather-Paul Bonanza, Lines Continue to Blur in Combat Sports
description: The norms within boxing and mixed martial arts shook yet again when Logan Paul fought Floyd Mayweather on Sunday without a satisfying conclusion. The pattern may continue.
content: For an instant on Sunday night, as Logan Paul stood in a boxing ring across Floyd Mayweather Jr., the best boxer of this generation, television cameras and microphones captured his astonishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Will You Go to Prom With Us?
description: Monday: The Times attended four pandemic-influenced proms across California. They were colorful, poignant and joyful.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: A Pact to Tax the World
description: A “historic” agreement by the G7 is a big step toward global tax coordination.
content: The Group of 7 finance chiefs sealed what they called a “historic global tax agreement” at a summit meeting in Britain this weekend. It was a diplomatic victory in particular for Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, who is leading the Biden administration’s push to collect trillions more in taxes from corporations and wealthy Americans to pay for its expansive spending proposals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2 Million Homes in California
description: A Tudor Revival cottage in San Francisco, a Spanish-style home by Cliff May in San Diego and a 1959 Joseph Eichler house in San Rafael.
content: This property is in Forest Hill, a San Francisco neighborhood developed in the 1910s, with wide streets (designed for horse-drawn carriages) lined with homes in a mix of Arts and Crafts and Tudor Revival styles. A chalet-inspired clubhouse, designed in 1919 by Bernard Maybeck, was restored in 2013 and is available for use by neighborhood residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: In Paris, Coco Gauff Is Confident, Consistent, and Off to the Quarterfinals
description: The 17-year-old, the last American player in singles, will face Barbora Krejcikova in her first Grand Slam tournament quarterfinal on Wednesday.
content: PARIS — It was Coco Gauff’s first appearance on the main stage at the French Open, and it was not the classic Parisian scene she had imagined with fewer than 100 fans in the stands at Court Philippe-Chatrier for the opening matches in this pandemic period of limited crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: In Guatemala, Harris Tells Undocumented to Stay Away From U.S. Border
description: In her first foreign trip as vice president, Kamala Harris promoted economic development and anti-corruption efforts, trying to stem the northward flow of migrants.
content: GUATEMALA CITY — During her first foreign trip as vice president, Kamala Harris said the United States would bolster investigations into corruption and human trafficking in Guatemala, while also delivering a clear, blunt message to undocumented migrants hoping to reach the United States: “Do not come.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: People Who Make New York Summer Happen
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 7, 2021.
content: “This is going to be a big summer. A lot of people have been cooped up, and now they want to go out and fish and they want their worms.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Rome Gets Its First Pizza Vending Machine. Will Romans Bite?
description: In a city with no shortage of pizza — or self-appointed food critics — an entrepreneur is betting on diners with a sense of adventure.
content: ROME — Romans eat pizza all the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub and Katrin Bennhold
title: From Doomsday Preppers to Doomsday Plotters
description: Far-right movements have long dreamed of a moment that ends society as we’ve known it. Now, experts say, so-called accelerationist thinking is proliferating in ways that could destabilize democracy.
content: For QAnon it is “The Storm,” when mass violence will topple the elite cabal of pedophiles who they imagine to be running the government. White-power groups in the United States have long promised a catastrophic race war. And in Germany and Austria, neo-Nazis herald an imagined putsch on “Day X” — when the democratic order collapses and they take over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Offshore Wind Farms Show What Biden’s Climate Plan Is Up Against
description: The U.S. has fallen way behind Europe partly because of an old shipping law and opposition from homeowners and fishing groups.
content: A constellation of 5,400 offshore wind turbines meet a growing portion of Europe’s energy needs. The United States has exactly seven.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Saffron Harvested by Female Farmers
description: Moonflowers is a new company that employs women in the Herat region of Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: High Heels Are Ready to Stomp Out Crocs and Birks
description: “I feel like a gazelle that’s just been born,” said one woman strapping back on the stilettos.
content: As she dressed for her 26th birthday recently, Cleo Pac Monrose focused on making a statement. Ms. Monrose, a podcast marketer for Spotify, flicked the dust off her party clothes and the high-heeled lavender pumps she had been hoarding since just before lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: You Can’t Rely on the C.D.C. to Make Your Pandemic Decisions
description: With the coronavirus ebbing, people can't rely on the C.D.C. to answer all their  questions. That's OK.
content: How should we think about the risk from Covid now?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Yellen’s New Alliance Against Leprechauns
description: Is the world finally ready to take on tax havens?
content: Over the weekend, largely at the urging of Janet Yellen, the Treasury secretary, finance ministers from the Group of 7 — the major advanced economies — agreed to set a minimum 15 percent tax rate on the profits of foreign subsidiaries of multinational corporations. You may wonder what that’s about, or why you should care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Here’s why both Mayweather and Paul are often considered controversial.
description: Both Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Logan Paul have been described as “controversial” in the run-up to their fight, and the word will likely make an appearance on the telecast tonight, so it is worth being specific about the troubles the fighters have faced in the past — which they have each used to promote this fight.
content: Both Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Logan Paul have been described as “controversial” in the run-up to their fight, and the word will likely make an appearance on the telecast tonight, so it is worth being specific about the troubles the fighters have faced in the past — which they have each used to promote this fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Bruce Springsteen Will Return to Broadway in June
description: “Springsteen on Broadway” opens on June 26 at the St. James Theater; audience members will be required to show proof of full Covid-19 vaccination to enter.
content: Bruce Springsteen is returning to Broadway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Kathryn Garcia Doesn’t Want to Be Anyone’s No. 2
description: Ms. Garcia, a former sanitation commissioner, was regarded as New York City’s problem solver. Now she faces her own challenge: persuading voters to elect a newcomer to politics.
content: Even for a New York City mayoral candidate who seemed like a long shot, the event early last month had a desperate quality to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Bill’s 44th’ Review: Where Are All the Party People?
description: This poignant, comic puppet play, by Dorothy James and Andy Manjuck, is as much about the ingenuity of the mind as it is about loneliness.
content: There are shows so delightfully unexpected that you hesitate, when writing about them, to give anything away. “Bill’s 44th” is one of those — a poignant, comic puppet play for grown-ups about a birthday party whose guests fail to appear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: As Warming Fuels Disasters, Relief Often Favors White People
description: The federal government often gives less help to Black disaster survivors than their white neighbors. That’s a challenge for President Biden, who has vowed to fight both inequality and climate change.
content: Roy Vaussine and Charlotte Biagas live in modest, single-story homes about a dozen miles apart in southwest Louisiana. When Hurricane Laura tore through their community last August, the damage was nearly identical. A tree crashed through the roof of each house. Neither had insurance. Each sought help from the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: As a Tense Summer Looms, Northern Ireland Braces
description: Brexit has inflamed sectarian passions to a degree not seen since the 1998 Good Friday Agreement.
content: BELFAST, Northern Ireland — The pandemic was hard on David Milliken, who sells drums, flags and pro-British banners from his brightly-colored shop in Sandy Row, a loyalist stronghold in Belfast. But now, he said, “things have started to open up again,” especially since “the unrest is back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift’s ‘Evermore’ Vaults to No. 1 With a Vinyl Bump
description: Taking advantage of a Billboard chart tweak in how the sales of physical albums are counted, the singer-songwriter’s six-month-old album returned to the top.
content: On the Friday before Memorial Day, Taylor Swift noted on social media that the vinyl version of her nearly six-month-old album “Evermore” was finally available. Pictured in her post lying in the grass with her LP, Swift informed her fans, “You can get it at your fav indie record store, Target, Walmart & Amazon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: How Joe Manchin Survives as a Democrat in West Virginia
description: Mr. Manchin stands in the way of the Biden administration’s expansive agenda. But in his home state, progressive Democrats with far-reaching policy goals are not his base — and he knows it.
content: With the fate of the progressive agenda depending on the support of Senator Joe Manchin III, who said again on Sunday that he would not abandon the filibuster to pass an expansive voting rights bill, interest groups and activists are gearing up for a full push to try to sway the moderate Democrat. It would be enough to make almost any Democratic politician in the country squirm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: She Was Stabbed and Left in a Cornfield in 1972. Now There’s an Arrest.
description: Barry Lee Whelpley, now 76, was charged with killing Julie Ann Hanson, who was 15 when her body was found in Naperville, Ill., the authorities said.
content: For nearly 50 years, the murder of Julie Ann Hanson, who was 15 when she was stabbed to death and her body was discovered in a cornfield, baffled investigators in a Chicago suburb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New York City Plans a Central Park Mega-Concert to Celebrate Reopening
description: The mayor’s office has asked the producer Clive Davis to sign up musical stars for an event on the Great Lawn in August.
content: Brunch crowds are back. Rush-hour traffic is back. Tourists in horse-drawn carriages are back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Won’t Hear Case on Limiting Military Draft to Men
description: The justices had been asked to decide whether one of the last sex-based distinctions in federal law should survive now that women can serve in combat.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear a challenge to a federal law that requires only men to register for the military draft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A warning about incitement in Israel.
content: Israel’s internal security director issued a rare public warning on Saturday night about what he called rising levels of incitement, days before a vote on the political coalition designed to oust Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Isaacs and Jorge Morales Toj
title: Guatemala Is America’s Best Chance to Fix the Immigration Problem
description: Is the Mayan vision of a full, plentiful and dignified life finally  within reach for all its citizens?
content: Vice President Kamala Harris arrived in Guatemala on Monday to kick off a two-day tour aimed at trying to strengthen ties with the country and tackle corruption, violence and poverty — the core issues behind the record number of migrants from Central America seeking entry into the United States. During a news conference in Guatemala City with President Alejandro Giammattei, Ms. Harris warned people not to come to the United States, adding that “the goal of our work is to help Guatemalans find hope at home.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Mayweather called this a ‘legalized bank robbery.’ Who knows how big the heist was.
description: Both fighters assuredly took home millions of dollars from Sunday night’s fight, but exactly how many millions of dollars is unknown.
content: Both fighters assuredly took home millions of dollars from Sunday night’s fight, but exactly how many millions of dollars is unknown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: This Summer, Make It Chianti Classico
description: Even in warmer weather, some occasions cry out for a red. This Tuscan wine is a gorgeous expression of sangiovese, with many excellent producers.
content: Here’s my wine for the summer: Chianti Classico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Vermont’s Governor Expands Voting Rights, Bucking Republican Push
description: Gov. Phil Scott signed a bill on Monday requiring that all registered voters receive mail-in ballots. His decision contrasted with Republican-led efforts to restrict voting rights in several states.
content: Gov. Phil Scott of Vermont signed legislation on Monday that requires all registered voters in the state to receive mail-in ballots, an expansion of voting rights that counters a movement among Republicans in other states to restrict them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By RiShawn Biddle
title: Don’t Kill Remote Learning. Black and Brown Families Need It.
description: Eliminating remote learning exacerbates existing educational and health care inequities.
content: Remote instruction. Virtual learning. School-by-Zoom. Whatever you want to call it, it has kept this Black man — along with my wife and 7-year-old son — safe from Covid over the last year, even if it hasn’t been easy on anyone. Each day, as my son sits at his desk in our home near Washington learning about bar graphs on a laptop screen, I am comforted by the knowledge that he’s not sitting in a poorly ventilated classroom at risk of getting sick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Ashley Southall
title: F.B.I. Investigates Cyberattack That Targeted N.Y.C. Law Department
description: City lawyers’ computer network was disabled after the attack, which the police and federal officials believe was the work of hackers.
content: An early clue that something was amiss with the computers at New York City’s Law Department — the 1,000-lawyer agency that represents the city in court — emerged on Monday when a lawyer for the department wrote to a federal judge in Manhattan, asking for a short delay in filing court papers because of “connectivity” problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Both Are Abuse Survivors, but One Can Sue and One Can’t
description: A proposed law in New York would clear the way for people who were abused after turning 18 to sue for damages.
content: SYRACUSE, N.Y. — After months of video calls and group emails, Robert Druger and Robert Bender agreed to meet for the first time on Memorial Day and revisit the places that had caused so much parallel anguish, four decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Left Needs the A.C.L.U. to Keep Defending Awful Speech
description: Yes, the civil liberties group is divided. What else is new?
content: I have a foggy childhood memory of being home sick from school and watching the 1981 movie “Skokie.” It tells the story of a planned neo-Nazi march through Skokie, Ill., a suburb full of Holocaust survivors, and the Jewish American Civil Liberties Union lawyer, based on David Goldberger, who defended the Nazis on free speech grounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck and Rebecca Robbins
title: F.D.A. Approves Alzheimer’s Drug Despite Fierce Debate Over Whether It Works
description: Aducanumab, or Aduhelm, is the first new Alzheimer’s treatment in 18 years and the first to attack the disease process. But some experts say there’s not enough evidence it can address cognitive symptoms.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Monday approved the first new medication for Alzheimer’s disease in nearly two decades, a contentious decision made despite opposition from the agency’s independent advisory committee and some Alzheimer’s experts who said there was not enough evidence that the drug can help patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: India’s revamped vaccine efforts.
content: Amid criticism of the government’s handling of the pandemic, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said in a nationwide address that the federal government would play a bigger role in getting vaccines on behalf of states. He also opened free shots up to everyone over 18.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Glou Up for an Orange Wine Purveyor
description: Doreen Winkler started with a subscription service for off-beat wines. Now she is opening a brick-and-mortar store on the Lower East Side.
content: In November 2019, Doreen Winkler started selling orange wines by subscription. Its success led her to open a wine shop specializing in the wines, which are white wines given enough skin contact to add a ruddy blush to the color. Orange Glou, the shop, is opening Friday with 100 different wines from many regions priced from $19 to $99. She points out that these “exciting” orange wines tend to be low in alcohol and great with food. Her inventory also includes some pét-nat bubblies. She said her audience tends to skew younger, under 50, and she’s pleased that chefs are among her fans. But keeping them in stock can be a challenge, she said, because wineries do not produce the styles in large quantities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Anna Dubenko
title: 16 Injured After Bus Crashes Into Brooklyn Home
description: An M.T.A. bus slammed into a historic rowhouse in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, injuring several people aboard the vehicle, the authorities said.
content: Sixteen people were injured, none of them critically, after a Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus crashed into a rowhouse in Brooklyn on Monday afternoon, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: June 7, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 7, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Manchin’s Bipartisan Ultimatum Becomes a Democratic Stumbling Block
description: Senator Joe Manchin’s push to have the parties work together has become a major obstacle for Democratic legislation on voting rights and other issues.
content: Six months into his role as majority leader, Senator Chuck Schumer is still trying to get Democrats’ legislative agenda into full gear. But the Senate Democratic caucus has a built-in brake system. Its name is Joe Manchin III.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: N.B.A. Fans Wanted a Show. They’re Also Getting a Reckoning.
description: The entertainment of the playoffs has been coupled with a pressing message from players that fans have disrespected them for too long.
content: Isaiah Thomas finally felt a conversation was in order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Biden, Congress and the Free Press
description: The Biden administration should break with Trump and Obama administration practices and stop targeting journalists.
content: If the First Amendment’s guarantee of a free press means anything, it has to mean that the government cannot seize reporters’ phone and email records in the hope of smoking out their confidential sources. This chilling tactic, which was used with increasing frequency during both the Obama and Trump administrations, makes it easier to prosecute leaks but harder for reporters to do their job and hold leaders to account. It represents a combination of official secrecy and information control that is anathema to democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: In Paris, Rafael Nadal Is the Same as Always, and Yet He’s Different
description: The player who turned defense into an art form fights to avoid the wars of attrition he battled as a younger athlete. At 35, that is what he must do.
content: PARIS — His hair is thinning on top. His knees can be shaky. In January, he suddenly came down with a balky back that almost forced him to withdraw from the Australian Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba, Ella Koeze and Jacob Silver
title: What Happened When Trump Was Banned on Social Media
description: Since Facebook and Twitter banned him, Donald J. Trump, the former president, has posted statements online far less often. But some of his statements have traveled just as far and wide on social networks.
content: Since Facebook and Twitter banned him, Donald J. Trump, the former president, has posted statements online far less often. But some of his statements have traveled just as far and wide on social networks.

title: Harris Warns Guatemalan Migrants Against Traveling to the U.S.

title: Justice Dept. Recovers Millions from Colonial Pipeline Hack
description: The Justice Department said on Monday that it had recovered the majority of the ransom paid to the hackers who shut down the computer systems of the Colonial Pipeline last month.
